comment_text.mn3:2.1: “Things of the flesh” renders āmisa, literally “meat”. In Vedic sacrifice the flesh of the slaughtered beast was made holy and fit for the gods (Rig Veda 1.162.10). In this way the guilt of killing was assuaged and the flesh became allowable for the brahmin priests. Here the “flesh” is extended by implication to the material pleasures of the world.
comment_text.mn3:2.4: Text’s ādiya (and variant ādissā) are future passive participles from √dis (“point”) having the sense “liable to be pointed out or accused”.
comment_text.mn3:3.1: A mendicant tries to eat just what they need. In some circumstances, especially when eating on invitation in a house, the donors will first place a modest amount of food in the bowl, then offer more during the meal if it is needed. This passage concerns such extra food that has been refused.
comment_text.mn3:3.25: This is an example of the “defilements given up by using” (MN 2:14.2). It makes a point: short term discomfort is outweighed by the benefits of overcoming greed. Note that the Buddha encouraged mendicants to eat regularly, and did not support fasting or other extreme diets.
comment_text.mn3:4.3: This marks the first time in the Majjhimanikāya that we hear a teaching from a disciple. Sāriputta was the Buddha’s leading disciple, famed for his wisdom. He gave many teachings in the suttas, typically, as here, preferring systematic expositions.
comment_text.mn3:5.1: Sāriputta continues on a similar theme, phrased in terms of “seclusion” (viveka) rather than “things of the flesh” (āmisa). Seclusion is explained in the commentaries as threefold: physical seclusion achieved by living a virtuous life in a quiet place; mental seclusion from the hindrances achieved through the jhānas; and seclusion from attachments, namely Nibbāna.
comment_text.mn3:6.5: “Senior mendicants” (therā bhikkhū) have been ordained for more than ten rains retreats, i.e. ten years.
comment_text.mn3:6.13: “Middle mendicants” (majjhimā bhikkhū) have between five and ten rains.
comment_text.mn3:6.14: “Junior mendicants” (navā bhikkhū) have less than five rains.
comment_text.mn3:8.2: Sāriputta is adapting a passage from the Buddha’s first sermon, the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:2.4).
comment_text.mn3:8.4: The noble eightfold path is the fourth of the four noble truths. It is defined in detail at MN 141:23.2.

translation_text.mn3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn3:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn3:2.1: “Mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.
translation_text.mn3:2.2: Out of sympathy for you, I think,
translation_text.mn3:2.3: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’
translation_text.mn3:2.4: If you become heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching, that will make you liable to the accusation:
translation_text.mn3:2.5: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching.’
translation_text.mn3:2.6: And it will make me liable to the accusation:
translation_text.mn3:2.7: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching.’
translation_text.mn3:2.8: If you become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh, that will make you not liable to the accusation:
translation_text.mn3:2.9: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn3:2.10: And it will make me not liable to the accusation:
translation_text.mn3:2.11: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn3:2.12: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.
translation_text.mn3:2.13: Out of sympathy for you, I think,
translation_text.mn3:2.14: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’
translation_text.mn3:3.1: Suppose that I had eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I needed.
translation_text.mn3:3.2: And there was some extra almsfood that was going to be thrown away.
translation_text.mn3:3.3: Then two mendicants were to come who were weak with hunger.
translation_text.mn3:3.5: ‘Mendicants, I have eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need.
translation_text.mn3:3.6: And there is this extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
translation_text.mn3:3.7: Eat it if you like. Otherwise I’ll throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.’
translation_text.mn3:3.8: Then one of those mendicants thought,
translation_text.mn3:3.9: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
translation_text.mn3:3.10: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
translation_text.mn3:3.11: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
translation_text.mn3:3.12: But the Buddha has also said:
translation_text.mn3:3.13: “Be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.”
translation_text.mn3:3.14: And almsfood is one of the things of the flesh.
translation_text.mn3:3.15: Instead of eating this almsfood, why don’t I spend this day and night weak with hunger?’
translation_text.mn3:3.17: Then the second of those mendicants thought,
translation_text.mn3:3.18: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
translation_text.mn3:3.19: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
translation_text.mn3:3.20: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
translation_text.mn3:3.21: Why don’t I eat this almsfood, then spend the day and night having got rid of my hunger and weakness?’
translation_text.mn3:3.23: Even though that mendicant, after eating the almsfood, spent the day and night rid of hunger and weakness, it is the former mendicant who is more worthy of respect and praise.
translation_text.mn3:3.25: Because for a long time that will conduce to that mendicant being of few wishes, content, self-effacing, unburdensome, and energetic.
translation_text.mn3:3.26: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.
translation_text.mn3:3.27: Out of sympathy for you, I think,
translation_text.mn3:3.28: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’”
translation_text.mn3:4.1: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn3:4.2: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
translation_text.mn3:4.3: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,
translation_text.mn3:5.1: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? And how do they train in seclusion?”
translation_text.mn3:5.2: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
translation_text.mn3:5.3: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.
translation_text.mn3:5.4: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn3:5.5: “Well then, reverends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn3:6.1: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion?
translation_text.mn3:6.2: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:6.3: They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
translation_text.mn3:6.4: They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:6.5: In this case, the senior mendicants should be criticized on three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:6.6: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’
translation_text.mn3:6.8: ‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
translation_text.mn3:6.10: ‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
translation_text.mn3:6.12: The senior mendicants should be criticized on these three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:6.13: In this case, the middle mendicants
translation_text.mn3:6.14: and the junior mendicants should be criticized on the same three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:6.22: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:7.1: And how do the disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion?
translation_text.mn3:7.2: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:7.3: They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
translation_text.mn3:7.4: They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:7.5: In this case, the senior mendicants should be praised on three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:7.6: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’
translation_text.mn3:7.8: ‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
translation_text.mn3:7.10: ‘They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
translation_text.mn3:7.12: The senior mendicants should be praised on these three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:7.13: In this case, the middle mendicants
translation_text.mn3:7.14: and the junior mendicants should be praised on the same three grounds.
translation_text.mn3:7.22: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
translation_text.mn3:8.1: The bad thing here is greed and hate.
translation_text.mn3:8.2: There is a middle way of practice for giving up greed and hate. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn3:8.3: And what is that middle way of practice?
translation_text.mn3:8.4: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn3:8.5: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn3:8.6: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn3:9-15.1: The bad thing here is anger and acrimony. …
translation_text.mn3:9-15.8: There is a middle way of practice for giving up vanity and negligence. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn3:9-15.9: And what is that middle way of practice?
translation_text.mn3:9-15.10: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn3:9-15.11: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn3:9-15.12: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.”
translation_text.mn3:9-15.13: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
